ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to write well with an eye to my own biases.
I learned how to analyze political writings from a variety of thinkers. Particularly, Professor Thompson helped me hone my analytical writing skills.

Some of the skills I learned included: analytic writing, close and critical reading, seminar discussion skills and starter questions. Through this class I also learned about the various ways many thinkers examined, viewed, and told history. From Hegel's arc of history to Arendt's reconciliation of the breaking down of society and civilization in the 20th century I learned about what my professor called history with a capital H. Alongside learning about how history was told and how power dynamics interacted with the narrative of history I learned about the social contract, different formulations of the state of nature, varying takes on majority, the power of a sovereign, and equality held by authors like Machiavelli, Locke, Hobbes, Rousseau, and Tocqueville.

A working knowledge of several main strands of post-medieval European political theory, with an emphasis on intertextuality. Contrasting with 1st semester H&P, this semester tied very neatly into the present, bringing a sense of urgency to the material.
I learned how to write a political thought paper, and covered major thinkers throughout history

better understanding of influential ideas in historical and political thought as well as insights on human nature (e.g. pain as the staying power of memory, development of human inner life as an effect of self-imposed repression of violent/carnal instincts, religion/conceptions of Hell as a means of self-punishment in Nietzsche; concentration camps and totalitarianism as destruction of human nature in Arendt)

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course is amazing, I feel much more well-read now.
Professor Thompson did an incredible job engaging us every day. The small seminar format provided an excellent venue for in-depth and informative discussions.

Strengths: Directed Studies H&P was consistently one of my favorite classes for its rigor and depth. I felt like I was able to make the most meaningful connections between texts and ideas and narratives of history in this class both in the spring and fall. In my section with Professor Thompson we touched the beginning of the readings through discussion starters which were student led and then we expanded to the rest of the text. This method of section allowed everyone to speak and also ensured that the major points of each reading were covered. Professor Thompson facilitated section so that we could delve into the passages with close reading and her extensive knowledge of the curriculum elevated our discussions and added complexity and clarity to my understanding of these authors - more so than any other class H&P with Professor Thompson gave me the skills to close read and look for complexity in the texts we engaged with.
Weaknesses: This is true across the DS curriculum, but the readings can be quite heavy and the pacing fast. That being said although there were readings which I did not take as much away from, for the most part in H&P my section delved into the readings with depth and intensity which gave me a better understanding and appreciation for the texts.

This was a fantastic seminar! It was well-run and engaging, and it integrated well with the format of zoom. The professor did a good job of bringing in modern day politics (which everyone in the class cared a lot about) without making it contentious, a careful balancing act. I think that most of the shortcomings of the course (mainly, staring at a screen is disengaging) were due to the format of zoom and would be solved by the class being in person.

As always in DS, the only thing that can really be improved upon is the reading list. There were some works that felt somewhat unnecessary or poorly done. For one, we spent far too long on Machiavelli. The Kant reading was also terribly uninformative, it felt disconnected from the conversations between the other thinkers. No one really responds to Kant's thought, and Kant basically just elaborates on one of Rousseau's theories. I wish we could have explored other important political theorists, like Grotius or Lenin.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think everything worked, though sometimes the lectures weren't posted on time.
I appreciated how accessible Professor Thompson's virtual office hours were.

I cannot think of an area which could be improved given the virtual format. Professor Thompson was an excellent seminar leader and our discussions never dragged or felt forced and on several occasions students shared their screens to add to our class.
As a first year I can't really comment.
virtual seminars worked well; asynchronous lectures were sometimes hard to keep up on but this is not necessarily a flaw in the course

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! DS is amazing and you'll be grateful you decided to do it.
Yes! Professor Thompson helped me grow as a writer, and I now have a good basis for the evolution of Western political thought.

Yes! DS H&P was consistently among my favorite of the DS tracks for its rigor, depth, and the vast array of connections and complexities it explores. Professor Thompson is an excellent seminar leader with her extensive knowledge of the texts she always pointed to important passages that added nuance to our discussions. My feedback on papers was always timely and constructive and I felt I became a much stronger writer by the end of the course. Although I was nervous at times in seminar I never felt intimidated about speaking - I definitely recommend this course if you are considering DS.
I would recommend this course to any student interested in receiving a broad look at the development of Western political thought.

Yes definitely! This course reignited my interest in political theory and made me want to revisit first semester texts with an eye for their larger historical significance. If you take this course, especially towards the end, you'll get this wonderful taste of all the connections between new ideas in political theory, literature, and philosophy (especially philosophy). It's immensely satisfying.
Yes, very much so. I enjoyed reading the works we studied, and Professor Thompson was an excellent professor.

Absolutely! If you want an understanding of political theory, and why many activists and people think the way they do, the seeds of all of it are found in the DS curriculum. The Left is Rousseau and Marx, and the Right are the Federalists and Burke! Locke is much more complex than history books make him out to be, as is Machiavelli. Nietzsche is utterly fascinating, and Dubois's telling of history is enlightening.

Take this class! It's perfectly structured to form your thinking!
yes, it gives a good intellectual foundation of historical/political ideas

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: recorded lectures in addition to seminars
Directed Studies Historical and Political Thought met two times a week for our virtual seminar. Alongside the seminar there were prerecorded lectures for each week.
Recorded lecture

recorded lecture
virtual seminar
